dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What would you like to talk about today?

Hey, thanks for having me. I've been feeling a bit unsure about choosing my major, especially since computer science wasn't the right fit for me. I'm leaning towards business administration but I've heard mixed reviews, and I'm also considering minors in French and Psychology. I'm just not sure if it's the right path or if it'll be too difficult.

It sounds like you're weighing a lot of options and feeling a bit uncertain about your next steps. What is it about business administration that draws your interest, and how do you feel about potentially taking on minors in French and Psychology?

client: Well, business administration seems practical, like it could open up a lot of job opportunities in the future. As for the minors, French seems useful because of its relevance here in Canada, and Psychology just sounds interesting to me. I'm just worried if I'm setting myself up for something too challenging.

It seems like you're drawn to business administration for its practicality and potential career benefits, while French and Psychology offer personal interest and relevance. Feeling worried about the challenge is understandable. What aspects of these subjects excite you or concern you the most?

I'm excited about the idea of understanding how businesses work and maybe getting into management or something like that. French is appealing because it could make me more marketable in Canada, and I just find Psychology fascinating—like understanding how people think and behave. But I'm concerned about whether I'll be able to keep up with the coursework, especially if business classes require a B- or better.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed their concerns about choosing a major and minors, highlighting the perceived benefits and potential challenges. The client's thoughts and feelings have been clearly articulated, and mutual understanding has been established. We can now transition to guiding the client to explore their motivations and potential changes.

dialogue.statement: Balancing excitement with concerns is a common experience. It sounds like you're motivated by practical career prospects and personal interests. How confident do you feel, on a scale of 0 to 10, about managing the coursework and achieving the grades you need?

client: Hmm, I'd say maybe around a 5 or 6? I feel like I could do it if I really put in the effort, but there's definitely a part of me that's worried about falling behind or not meeting the grade requirements.
It's insightful that you're recognizing both your motivation and your concerns. What might help you shift that confidence from a 5 or 6 to a higher number?

client(guiding): I guess having a better idea of what to expect from the classes would help, like knowing the workload or the types of assignments. Maybe talking to professors or students who are already in the major could give me a clearer picture. Also, finding good study strategies or time management tips might boost my confidence.

Gaining perspective from those already in the field could certainly provide valuable insights. Exploring effective study strategies and time management techniques can also enhance your confidence. What small step might you take next to gather more information or resources?

client(guiding): I think I could start by reaching out to some upperclassmen or professors in the business department to get their take on the major. Maybe I'll also look for some workshops or resources on campus about study skills or time management. That sounds like a good start to getting a better sense of things.

statement.reasoning: The client has shown Change Talk by identifying specific steps to increase confidence, such as reaching out to upperclassmen and attending workshops. Confidence is at a 5 or 6 but can be improved with identified actions. Discrepancy between practical career goals and current uncertainty has been explored. Readiness indicators suggest moving to action planning.

dialogue.statement: Reaching out to upperclassmen and professors sounds like a solid plan to gather firsthand insights. Looking into campus workshops for study skills and time management is also a proactive approach. Based on what you've mentioned, would you like to set a goal for reaching out to one or two people this week, and perhaps attend at least one workshop? How might you monitor your progress with these actions?

client(choosing): Yeah, setting that goal sounds doable. I can try reaching out to a couple of people this week and see if there are any workshops I can attend. Maybe I'll keep track by jotting down what I learn from these conversations and any strategies I pick up. That way, I can see how I'm progressing and what else I need to do.

Creating a plan to connect with upperclassmen and professors, along with attending workshops, sounds like a proactive step forward. By jotting down what you learn and tracking your strategies, you'll have a clear view of your progress. How do you feel about setting a specific day this week to start reaching out, and what support might you need to stay on track?

client(choosing): I think I could aim to start reaching out by Wednesday. That gives me a couple of days to figure out who to contact and how to approach them. As for support, maybe just checking in with you or someone else to stay accountable could help, so I don't keep putting it off.

Setting Wednesday as your starting point gives you a focused timeline to prepare, which is great. Checking in for accountability definitely helps keep the momentum going. Would you like a follow-up to discuss how things are progressing, or is there anyone else you feel comfortable reaching out to for support?

client(choosing): Yeah, a follow-up would be helpful. It’d be nice to have someone to talk to about how it’s going and maybe get some feedback or advice if needed. I can also think about if there are any friends or mentors I could reach out to for some extra support along the way.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal and action plan, which includes reaching out to upperclassmen and professors, attending workshops, and monitoring progress. The client has expressed commitment by setting a timeline and seeking accountability. They are also open to follow-ups for further support. These elements indicate readiness to move forward.

dialogue.statement: Looking forward to our follow-up. You've set a robust plan in motion with reaching out by Wednesday and gathering insights that will surely guide you. Identifying friends or mentors for that extra layer of support is such a great idea too. Remember, every step you take is progress, and you're doing an excellent job by taking these proactive steps. Until we check in, keep tracking your achievements and recognize your efforts—you've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate the support and encouragement. I'll keep you posted on how things go and make sure to reach out if I need any advice. Looking forward to our next session!

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear plan, including reaching out by Wednesday and attending workshops, with follow-up and accountability established. Progress tracking and extra support are in place, fulfilling termination goals.

concern:
title: Should I Major in business administration ( B.A)
Hey everyone, 

I am a first-year student at a university and I am still not sure what major should I select I tried Computer science but it was way too hard for me, and of the other majors  Business administration stood out to me as something useful, but I have read on Reddit and other forums by some people that it is not very good of a major, I am thinking of doing a minor in French ( French is an official language here in Canada so this is something that is pretty useful to study here )  and Psychology ( minor ) to go with it? And also is Business administration something that is very hard? Because my degree required me to have B- in every business course I think. I appreciate your answers and am sorry for any typos or mistakes English is not my first language.

&#x200B;

Thanks.
